facts.text: Appellant is the owner of Shankar Tukaram Karale Rampur Farm, situated at the tail-outlet of the Godavari Right Bank Canal Distributary No. 17.

Lands originally belonged to Shankar Tukaram Karale (Karale). In 1935, Karale had a farm for raising sugarcane consisting of 35 acres owned by him and about 65 acres leased in Ahmednagar District. He obtained sanction to irrigate his lands on outlet No. 17.
In or about 1935, Government of Bombay proposed to reserve certain area along Distributary Canal as factory area.

After correspondence, Superintending Engineer agreed on July 14, 1939, to exclude Karale's lands from factory area and give water perpetually on condition that he concentrated holdings on tail outlet of Distributary No. 17 and took supply on volumetric basis.
Karale concentrated his holdings by purchase or otherwise and shifted operations; supplied water on agreed basis.
In April 1948, appellant and Karale entered partnership for the area (appellant 3/4 share, Karale 1/4).
Disputes led to consent decree dated February 7, 1951; appellant became full owner of partnership business, assets, liabilities, lands, compact block, and right to canal water.
Canal Officer refused recognition of transfer. On appeal, informed request for supply could not be granted. From April 1952, supply stopped.

After statutory notice under s.80 CPC, appellant filed Special Civil Suit No. 6 of 1953 in Civil Judge, Senior Division, Ahmednagar, against State of Bombay for declaration of entitlement to water supply for 100 acres, specific performance, damages, etc.
State contended no concluded agreement, or void under s.175(3) GOI Act 1935, and appellant could not get benefit under s.30 Bombay Irrigation Act.
Civil Judge held concluded agreement but transfer violated Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act 1948; dismissed suit.
High Court (judgment August 22, 1960, appeal No. 432 of 1954) held no concluded agreement or did not comply with law; dismissed appeal.

Exhibits D-67 and D-68 dated July 14, 1939: Superintending Engineer allowed concentration of 100 acres cane irrigation on tail outlet permanently, volumetric basis, excluded from factory area; Karale agreed.
Government sent draft agreements in 1942 and 1950, not executed fully.
Yearly applications under Act made and water supplied.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was a concluded agreement between Karale and Government for perpetual water supply on volumetric basis from tail outlet of Distributary No. 17.
Whether the agreement was entered under Bombay Irrigation Act 1879 or outside it, and thus subject to s.175(3) GOI Act 1935.
Whether the agreement complied with s.175(3) GOI Act 1935 (expressed in name of Governor and executed on his behalf).
Whether right under agreement transferred to appellant under s.30 Bombay Irrigation Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Concluded agreement between Karale and Canal Officer for water to compact block permanently from tail outlet on volumetric basis.
Right transferred to appellant via compromise decree under s.30 Bombay Irrigation Act 1879.
s.175(3) GOI Act 1935 does not apply: (i) power under statute, not executive; (ii) agreement under Act; (iii) 'agreement' in s.30 means sanction/permission, not formal contract.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.175(3) GOI Act 1935; s.30 Bombay Irrigation Act

respondent_arguments.text: No concluded agreement embodying alleged terms.
Even if agreement, void as did not comply with s.175(3) GOI Act 1935.
Appellant could not legally get benefit under s.30 Bombay Irrigation Act 1879.

court_reasoning.text: Exhibits D-67 and D-68 record concluded agreement: Karale to concentrate 100 acres cane on tail outlet by 15-2-1940, continue permanently if wished, volumetric basis 11/2' depth, pay rates; area excluded from factory; Karale agreed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Firm agreement entered; 'permanently' applies to supply as cultivation requires water.

court_reasoning.text: Agreement outside Bombay Irrigation Act (no provision for such application to exclude from factory area or permanent supply); made by Government via Minister's orders to Superintending Engineer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not under ss.27-30; parties understood as Government-Karale agreement; drafts sent later unexecuted.

court_reasoning.text: As outside Act, falls under executive authority; must comply with s.175(3) GOI Act 1935: not expressed in Governor's name, not executed on his behalf by authorised person.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Documents do not show authority or expression in Governor's name; mandatory provision.

court_reasoning.text: Followed Seth Bikhraj and New Marine Coal; distinguished Rallia Ram (no inference possible here).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot stretch construction to make s.175(3) nugatory.

holdings.text: Concluded agreement existed between Government and Karale for water supply.
Agreement made outside Bombay Irrigation Act in exercise of executive authority.
Agreement void for non-compliance with s.175(3) GOI Act 1935.

precedents_cited.case_name: Seth Bikhraj Jaipuria v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: s.175(3) GOI Act 1935 mandatory; contracts not expressed in Governor's name or executed on behalf void.

precedents_cited.case_name: New Marine Coal Co. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Reaffirmed Seth Bikhraj on mandatory nature of s.175(3).

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Rallia Ram
precedents_cited.relevance: Contract could be inferred as on behalf of Governor from context; not applicable here as documents lack such indication.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Irrigation Act, 1879
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs applications for water supply, permissions, transfers; agreement not under these provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Contracts in exercise of executive authority must be expressed in Governor's name and executed on his behalf; mandatory, agreement void for non-compliance.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Lower court held transfer violated this; not addressed by SC.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held concluded agreement existed but was outside Bombay Irrigation Act and void under s.175(3) GOI Act 1935 for not being expressed in Governor's name or properly executed; appeal dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "A fair reading of these two documents leaves no room for doubt that a firm agreement was entered into between the Government and Karale in respect of the supply of water to his land to the extent of 100 acres on the tail outlet of Distributary No. 17."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The provisions of s.175(3) of the Government of India Act, 1935, were mandatory and, therefore, the contracts were void."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We cannot, therefore, hold that either the contract was entered into by the person legally authorized by the Government to do so or expressed to be made in the name of the Governor. The agreement is void."
key_quotes.speaker: court
